title: Family & Money
description: Explore how family relationships intersect with your financial life.

questions.text: When it comes to financially helping family members, I believe...
choices: We should help when we can—family comes first
We need to take care of ourselves before others
It depends on the situation and our relationship
We should discuss it together case by case

therapeutic.rationale: Family financial support is a major tension point for couples. Family-firsters prioritize obligation; self-firsters prioritize boundaries; situational types evaluate; discussers want partnership. Unspoken expectations cause conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The family-first person may feel their partner is selfish; the self-first person may feel their partner is enmeshed. Both are usually trying to protect something important. Name your values.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy prevents a common conflict. You'll naturally agree on when and how to help family.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What obligations do you feel toward family financially? Where does that sense of obligation come from?

questions.text: If family wanted to give us financial help, I'd feel...
choices: Grateful—it's generous and I'd accept
Hesitant—I prefer to be independent
Complicated—it depends on the strings attached
Like we should discuss it together first

therapeutic.rationale: Receiving family help brings up independence, obligation, and power. Grateful-accepters see generosity; hesitant types guard independence; complicated-feelers see strings; discussers want partnership. These feelings often surprise us.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The accepter may not understand the hesitant partner's discomfort; the hesitant partner may not understand why the accepter wants to take the help. Talk about what the money means, not just the money.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared feelings make these situations easier. You'll naturally respond the same way to family generosity.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about accepting help from family? What does it mean to you when you do?

questions.text: The financial lessons I learned from my family are...
choices: Mostly positive—I want to carry them forward
Mixed—some I'll keep, some I'll change
Mostly things I want to do differently
Something I haven't thought much about

therapeutic.rationale: Family financial patterns pass down through generations. Positive-inheritors continue patterns; mixed-inheritors select; change-seekers break patterns; unexamined types may repeat unconsciously. Awareness allows choice.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family experiences shape different financial instincts. The positive-inheritor may not understand why their partner wants to change everything. Share your family money stories.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared orientation toward family patterns means you're doing similar work. Support each other's financial growth journey.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What money lessons did your family teach you—spoken or unspoken? Which do you want to keep?

questions.text: When family and money create tension, I tend to...
choices: Protect the family relationship first
Protect our financial boundaries first
Try to find a middle ground
Feel stressed and unsure how to handle it

therapeutic.rationale: Family-money tension reveals loyalties and priorities. Relationship-protectors prioritize harmony; boundary-protectors prioritize limits; middle-grounders balance; stressed types need support. This often becomes a couple conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The relationship-protector may feel their partner doesn't value family; the boundary-protector may feel their partner doesn't prioritize them. Both loyalties matter—how can you honor both?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared tendency means you'll approach family-money conflict similarly. This alignment helps when issues arise.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a time family and money created tension. How did you handle it? What would you do differently?

questions.text: Talking about money with my family feels...
choices: Natural—we're pretty open about it
Awkward—we don't really discuss it
Complicated—there's history there
Different than talking about it with my partner

therapeutic.rationale: Family money communication patterns shape our comfort with financial conversations. Open-family backgrounds normalize money talk; awkward-family backgrounds create avoidance; complicated histories add emotional weight. These patterns follow us.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family communication styles may mean different comfort levels. The open-family partner may push for conversations the awkward-family partner finds uncomfortable. Go at the pace of the less comfortable person.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared family communication patterns mean similar comfort levels. You understand each other's baseline.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How did your family talk (or not talk) about money? How does that affect your relationship now?
